entry.title: Meta Has Deprecated the Messenger Apps for Mac and Windows Too
entry.content:
Ryan Christoffel, reporting for 9to5Mac a month ago:

Meta has published a support doc that states its Messenger app for Mac is being discontinued. New users won‚Äôt be able to download the app at all, and existing users have about 60 more days of use before it stops working altogether. Why the change? Unfortunately, no reason has been given. But users are being pushed to the Facebook website for all their Messenger needs instead.

There‚Äôs a nearly identical support document for the native Messenger app for Windows too. They‚Äôre not even replacing them with web-app wrappers, like they just did with the Windows WhatsApp client. Just telling users to use the website.

entry.title: [Sponsor] Clerk for iOS
Google Announces Private AI Compute
entry.content:
Jay Yagnik, VP of AI innovation and research, on Google‚Äôs The Keyword blog:

Private AI Compute is built on a multi-layered system that is designed from the ground up around core security and privacy principles:

  • One integrated Google tech stack: Private AI Compute runs on one seamless Google stack powered by our own custom Tensor Processing Units (TPUs). World-class privacy and security is integrated into this architecture with Titanium Intelligence Enclaves (TIE). This design enables Google AI features to use our most capable and intelligent Gemini models in the cloud, with our high standards for privacy and the same in-house computing infrastructure you already rely on for Gmail and Search.
  • No access: Remote attestation and encryption are used to connect your device to the hardware-secured sealed cloud environment, allowing Gemini models to securely process your data within a specialized, protected space. This ensures sensitive data processed by Private AI Compute remains accessible only to you and no one else, not even Google.

Sounds a lot like Apple‚Äôs Private Cloud Compute, which raises the question of whether this Google project is related to the Gurman scoop that Apple and Google are on the cusp of a deal for a white-label version of Google Gemini to run on Apple‚Äôs Private Cloud Compute servers to power the next-generation versions of Siri and Apple Intelligence.

I strongly suspect this is something Google has been working on for a while. Apple, I think it‚Äôs fair to say, places a higher priority on privacy than does Google, but Google does value privacy. But perhaps the deal with Apple accelerated the project within Google.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: OpenAI: Piloting Group Chats in ChatGPT
entry.content:
OpenAI:

To start a group chat tap the people icon in the top right corner of any new or existing chat. When you add someone to an existing chat, ChatGPT creates a copy of your conversation as a new group chat so your original conversation stays separate. You can invite others directly by sharing a link with one to twenty people, and anyone in the group can share that link to bring others in. When you join or create your first group chat, you‚Äôll be asked to set up a short profile with your name, username, and photo so everyone knows who‚Äôs in the conversation. Group chats can be found in a new clearly-labeled section of the sidebar for easy access. [...]

Group chats are separate from your private conversations. Your personal ChatGPT memory is not used in group chats, and ChatGPT does not create new memories from these conversations. We‚Äôre exploring offering more granular controls in the future so you can choose if and how ChatGPT uses memory with group chats.

Currently rolling out in Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, and Taiwan. Rate limits and advanced model usage depend on the group member to whom ChatGPT replies. Pretty clever, and I can imaging a lot of ways this would be useful, both for family/friends and for work collaboration. I like the idea that this is built into ChatGPT, not an AI bot in a regular messaging app. This way, you know with certainty which of your chats are being seen and read by an AI bot.

We‚Äôve also taught ChatGPT new social behaviors for group chats. It follows the flow of the conversation and decides when to respond and when to stay quiet based on the context of the group conversation. You can always mention ‚ÄúChatGPT‚Äù in a message when you want it to respond. We‚Äôve also given ChatGPT the ability to react to messages with emojis, and reference profile photos‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâso it can, for example, use group members‚Äô photos when asked to create fun personalized images within that group conversation.

This is a really hard problem to solve. Wavelength, the late great private group messaging app whose team I advised from 2023 to 2024 (when the app shuttered), added AI chatbots (with customizable personalities) in June 2023. Wavelength‚Äôs AI bots only responded when mentioned explicitly.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Financial Times: ‚ÄòApple Intensifies Succession Planning for CEO Tim Cook‚Äô
entry.content:
The Financial Times, under a four-person byline (‚ÄúTim Bradshaw, Stephen Morris, and Michael Acton in San Francisco, and Daniel Thomas in London‚Äù):

Apple is stepping up its succession planning efforts, as it prepares for Tim Cook to step down as chief executive as soon as next year. Several people familiar with discussions inside the tech group told the Financial Times that its board and senior executives have recently intensified preparations for Cook to hand over the reins at the $4tn company after more than 14 years.

John Ternus, Apple‚Äôs senior vice-president of hardware engineering, is widely seen as Cook‚Äôs most likely successor, although no final decisions have been made, these people said.

People close to Apple say the long-planned transition is not related to the company‚Äôs current performance, ahead of what is expected to be a blockbuster end-of-year sales period for the iPhone. [...]

The company is unlikely to name a new CEO before its next earnings report in late January, which covers the critical holiday period. An announcement early in the year would give its new leadership team time to settle in ahead of its big annual keynote events, its developer conference in June and its iPhone launch in September, the people said. These people said that although preparations have intensified, the timing of any announcement could change.

I have no little-birdie insight on this, but that‚Äôs not surprising. I don‚Äôt think there are many people, if any, outside Apple‚Äôs top executive team and board of directors who have any insight into Cook‚Äôs thinking on this. That ‚Äúseveral people‚Äù spoke to the FT about this says to me that those sources (members of the board?) did so with Cook‚Äôs blessing, and they want this announcement to be no more than a little surprising.

I absolutely love the idea of Cook‚Äôs successor being a product person like Ternus, and Ternus is young enough‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ50, the same age Cook was in 2011 when he took the reins from Steve Jobs‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâto hold the job for a long stretch. Ternus took over iPhone hardware engineering in 2020, and was promoted to senior vice president of hardware engineering in January 2021, when Dan Riccio stepped aside. Apple‚Äôs hardware, across all product lines and including silicon, has been exemplary under Ternus‚Äôs leadership. And Ternus clearly loves and understands the Mac.

I would also bet that Cook moves into the role of executive chairman, and will still play a significant, if not leading, role for the company when it comes to domestic and international politics. Especially with regard to Trump.

 ‚òÖ

entry.summary: The question is, did Meta scrap its native Windows app because they don‚Äôt care that much about Windows in particular? Or because they don‚Äôt care that much about native desktop apps, period‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand a crude web app wrapper is coming to Mac next?
entry.content:
Mayank Parmar, writing for Windows Latest:

WhatsApp on Windows 11 has just got a ‚Äúmajor‚Äù upgrade, and you‚Äôre probably going to hate it because it simply loads web.whatsapp.com in a WebView2 container. This means WhatsApp on Windows 11 is cooked, and it‚Äôs back to being absolute garbage in terms of performance.

WhatsApp is one of those Windows apps that went from being a web wrapper to a native app and then back to the web again after all these years of investment. WhatsApp for Windows was originally an Electron app, and it was eventually replaced with UWP after years of investment. Four years later, WhatsApp is going back to WebView2, abandoning the original WinUI/UWP native idea. [...]

An app can use a lot of memory, and it does not necessarily mean it‚Äôs a performance nightmare, but the issue with the new WhatsApp is that it feels sluggish. You‚Äôre going to notice sluggish performance, long loading time, and other performance issues when browsing different conversations.

We also noticed that it does not work well with Windows notifications. It also struggles with Windows 11‚Äôs Do Not Disturb mode or Active Hours. And there are delayed notifications problems as well.

I found this post interesting on a few fronts.

First, from the perspective of Meta. They replaced a shitty web app wrapper for Windows with a modern native Windows app, one that seemingly pleased Windows aficionados like Parmar. And now they‚Äôve thrown that app away, going back to what that native app replaced four years ago: a web app wrapper that is bloated, slow, and unsurprisingly has poor support for native Windows features. It‚Äôs bad enough that so many large companies never even bother creating native apps, but it feels even worse to see a good native app abandoned.

Second, it‚Äôs interesting reading Parmar‚Äôs list of gripes about the new web-app-wrapper WhatsApp app. All his gripes have merit, but it struck me that none of them are about the UI. Maybe the web app‚Äôs UI is actually fine? I have no idea. But I suspect it‚Äôs more that the Windows nerd mindset has UI design quality and adherence to recommended platform idioms way down on their list of priorities. That‚Äôs why they‚Äôre Windows users, not Mac users.

Lastly, I wonder if this bodes poorly for the future of the current WhatsApp app for MacOS, a native app written using Mac Catalyst, Apple‚Äôs framework for porting iOS UIKit apps to the Mac. Like most Catalyst apps, WhatsApp for Mac isn‚Äôt a good Mac app. It doesn‚Äôt support the Services menu at all. It doesn‚Äôt let you open chats into standalone windows, or open more than one chat window. It opens its Settings right in its one main window. The whole ‚Äúthere‚Äôs only one window, and everything is in that one window‚Äù design is very iOS. The menu bar is a HIG prescriptivist‚Äôs nightmare. All the multi-word menu commands are in Sentence case rather than Title Case (except, of course, for the menu commands that come ‚Äúfree‚Äù with Catalyst‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâhow do the developers of the app not notice this?), and the menu title order goes: File, Chat, Edit, Call, View, Window, Help (obviously it should be File, Edit, View, Chat, Call, Window, Help). Has there ever once, in 41 years, been a good Mac app that puts a menu between ‚ÄúFile‚Äù and ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù?

But, still, WhatsApp for Mac is a better Mac app than any Electron app I‚Äôve ever used. Examining it now, it seems lightweight on both CPU usage and memory. It feels a bit better to me than either Signal or Beeper, both of which are developed using Electron, and both of which consume more RAM than WhatsApp. To name just one obvious nicety: when you send a new message in an older chat in WhatsApp, that chat animates as it moves to the top of the list of chats. It slides up, and other chats slide down as they re-sort. In the Signal and Beeper apps for Mac, an updated chat just zaps to the top of the chat list, with no animation at all. Gross.

The question is, did Meta scrap its native Windows app because they don‚Äôt care that much about Windows in particular? Or because they don‚Äôt care that much about native desktop apps, period‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand a crude web app wrapper is coming to Mac next? WhatsApp for Mac is currently the top-ranked free app in the Mac App Store‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut it‚Äôs also the top-ranked free Windows app in the Microsoft Store. Meta did just ship a native Apple Watch app for WhatsApp, but if you want an app for WatchOS, it has to be native. You can‚Äôt ship a web app wrapper like an Electron app there.

Personally, I won‚Äôt care too much if Meta shitcans the WhatsApp Mac app, because I barely use WhatsApp. But outside America, WhatsApp is the dominant messaging platform in much (most?) of the world. I‚Äôd be worried if I were a Mac user who uses WhatsApp heavily.
entry.title: ‚òÖ Meta Replaced the Native Windows WhatsApp App With a Shitty Web App
The Information: Second-Gen iPhone Air Postponed Until Spring 2027, but Might Gain Second Camera
entry.content:
Wayne Ma and Qianer Liu, reporting for The Information on Tuesday (paywalled, alas, but summarized by 9to5Mac here and here):

Apple has since sharply scaled back production of the first iPhone Air and delayed the release of an updated version that was meant to launch in fall 2026, The Information reported earlier this week.

Instead, some Apple engineers are hoping to release a redesigned version with a second camera lens in spring 2027 alongside existing plans to release the standard iPhone 18 and iPhone 18e at that time. It‚Äôs still too early to tell whether they can successfully redesign the iPhone Air in time to make that new release window, the people said.

My question: Would that second camera provide an ultra-wide (0.5√ó) or a telephoto (3√ó or 4√ó) lens? The regular non-pro iPhones provide an ultra-wide lens as their second camera. But when the premium iPhones had only two (rather than three) lenses, the second lens was telephoto, not ultra-wide. Apple first used the adjective ‚ÄúPro‚Äù with the iPhones 11 Pro and Pro Max, and all iPhones to date with ‚ÄúPro‚Äù in their name have had three lenses. But the iPhones XS (2018), X (2017), 8 Plus (also 2017), and 7 Plus (2016) all had 1√ó main and 2√ó ‚Äútelephoto‚Äù lenses.

In other words, when a premium iPhone had only one extra lens, that lens added additional reach, not ultra-wide perspective. The iPhone Air costs more than a regular no-adjective iPhone, so if that patterns holds, a two-camera second-generation model would add a telephoto, not ultra-wide lens. Personally I‚Äôm hoping that‚Äôs what Apple will do.

Looking at my own photo library and using smart albums to count the photos I‚Äôve taken using each particular lens on each particular iPhone, roughly speaking, over the past few years, I shoot about 10 percent of my photos with the ultra-wide lens, 10 percent with the telephoto, and 80 percent with the main. But a lot of my ultra-wide photos are really just close-up macro shots of things like product labels. If I were less lazy, I‚Äôd go through them and trash a lot of them. I could capture equivalent photos, for a lot of these throwaway macro shots, with the main 1√ó camera lens just by holding the phone a little further from the subject. Adding a 0.5√ó ultra-wide to the iPhone Air just wouldn‚Äôt add much utility, at least for me, compared to the obvious utility of a telephoto lens with more reach.

(The iPhone Air‚Äôs lone 1√ó camera has a minimum focus distance of 15 cm; the minimum focus distance of the 1√ó cameras on the iPhones 17 Pro, 16 Pro, and 15 Pro is 20 cm. That 5 cm difference is a largely unheralded advantage for the iPhone Air‚Äôs camera, and significantly makes up for the lack of an ultra-wide lens for close-up photography. 5 cm doesn‚Äôt sound like much, but in practice it‚Äôs very noticeable. That said, for actual macro photography, the 0.5√ó ultra-wide camera on the iPhone Pro models has a minimum focus distance of just 2 cm.)

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: WSJ Report on the iPhone Air Pegs It as a ‚ÄòFlop‚Äô
entry.content:
Rolfe Winkler and Yang Jie, reporting for The Wall Street Journal (gift link, News+ link) under the headline ‚ÄúApple‚Äôs iPhone Air Is a Marketing Win and a Sales Flop‚Äù (which headline, going from the web page <title> element, was originally the less sensational ‚ÄúApple‚Äôs iPhone Air Sales Disappoint‚Äù):

Jason Purdy wanted to like his new iPhone Air.

Raised in Apple‚Äôs hometown of Cupertino, Calif., and later an Apple senior product manager, Purdy said he loves to see innovative product design from tech companies. So he made an Apple store appointment to buy the new, ultrathin smartphone the day it went on sale.

Within a month, he returned it.

He found it hard to have speakerphone calls and listen to music. And the photos he took at his early October wedding came out noticeably worse than ones his brother took on a new iPhone 17 Pro.

‚ÄúThe performance wasn‚Äôt quite there. Across the board they‚Äôre sacrificing all these things,‚Äù said Purdy. The Air was very pleasurable to hold and impressed his friends, but didn‚Äôt work as his primary device, he said.

That‚Äôs a brutally unfair lede to this story without showing the photos. If Purdy‚Äôs brother‚Äôs photos (taken with an iPhone 17 Pro) were all taken with the telephoto 4√ó lens, and all of Purdy‚Äôs photos (taken with an iPhone Air) were from telephoto distance and he relied on digital zoom, then yes, his photos from the Air surely did look noticeably worse. But the lone (1√ó) camera on the Air is very good. It‚Äôs not as good as the main 1√ó camera on the iPhone 17 Pro, but it‚Äôs close enough that in most people‚Äôs hands, the difference isn‚Äôt perceptible. And between comparably talented amateur photographers, someone using an iPhone Air at a wedding, and using their feet to ‚Äúzoom‚Äù by getting close to the subjects of their photos, will take way better pictures than someone shooting from across the room using the iPhone 17 Pro‚Äôs telephoto 4√ó lens. When it comes to optical quality, the Air‚Äôs 1√ó lone camera is obviously superior to the 17 Pro‚Äôs telephoto.

Saying that ‚Äúthe photos ... came out noticeably worse‚Äù with no explanation of what type of photos they were, let alone, you know, actually showing example images, is just a dirty trick. There are numerous valid reasons why someone might prefer a 17 Pro to an Air for photography, but what the Journal describes regarding this guy Purdy and his brother doesn‚Äôt describe such a situation. Someone who just wants to shoot some nice photos at a family gathering like a wedding can get terrific results from an iPhone Air. Show me someone who says the iPhone Air is a poor camera and I‚Äôll show you a terrible photographer who doesn‚Äôt know what the fuck they‚Äôre talking about.

The Air is billed as Apple‚Äôs thinnest smartphone yet.

It is Apple‚Äôs thinnest smartphone yet. You can measure it.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Tesla Is Working on CarPlay Support
entry.content:
Mark Gurman and Edward Ludlow, reporting for Bloomberg (paywalled, alas, but summarized by The Verge and Ars Technica)

Tesla Inc. is developing support for Apple Inc.‚Äôs CarPlay system in its vehicles, according to people with knowledge of the matter, working to add one of the most highly requested features by customers. The carmaker has started testing the capability internally, according to the people, who asked not to be identified because the effort is still private. [...]

Adding CarPlay would mark a stunning reversal for Tesla and Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk, who long ignored pleas to implement the popular feature. Musk has criticized Apple for years, particularly its App Store policies, and was angered by the company‚Äôs poaching of his engineers when it set out to build its own car.

I wouldn‚Äôt call it a ‚Äústunning‚Äù reversal, but it would certainly be a reversal. And it would really show what a bonehead move it is for GM to be dropping CarPlay support.

Alphabet Inc.‚Äôs Google offers a CarPlay competitor called Android Auto for devices running its operating system. But Tesla isn‚Äôt actively developing support for it.

Like I just wrote the other day: a significant chunk of new-car buyers consider CarPlay support a dealbreaker, but, effectively no one cares about Android Auto. CarPlay support might make a difference for a company like Tesla, whose sales are in the tank. Android Auto support would not.

 ‚òÖ

entry.summary: With the other personalities, you‚Äôre choosing between flavors of bullshit. With Efficient, you‚Äôre choosing no bullshit.
entry.content:
OpenAI today, ‚ÄúGPT-5.1: A Smarter, More Conversational ChatGPT‚Äù:

GPT‚Äë5.1 Instant, ChatGPT‚Äôs most used model, is now warmer by default and more conversational. Based on early testing, it often surprises people with its playfulness while remaining clear and useful.

These changes seem to be in direct response to the ChatGPT users who convinced themselves they had developed personal friendships with the 4o and 4.5 models, and who were very upset with the technically superior but less emotionally engaging 5.0 models.

Here are OpenAI‚Äôs example responses, quoted in their announcement, to the prompt ‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling stressed and could use some relaxation tips.‚Äù (I‚Äôm quoting only the first few paragraphs of the responses, which are enough to note the tone.)

GPT-5:

Here are a few simple, effective ways to help ease stress‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâyou can mix and match depending on how you‚Äôre feeling and how much time you have:

üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èÔ∏è Quick Reset (1‚Äì5 minutes)

  • Deep breathing: Try the 4-7-8 method‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâinhale for 4 seconds, hold for 7, exhale for 8. Repeat 4 rounds.
  • Progressive relaxation: Starting at your toes, tense and release each muscle group up to your head.
  • Grounding: Look around and name 5 things you see, 4 things you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste. Brings you into the moment fast.

[192 additional words and 3 section-heading emoji omitted.]

GPT-5.1 Instant:

I‚Äôve got you, Ron‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat‚Äôs totally normal, especially with everything you‚Äôve got going on lately. Here are a few ways to decompress depending on what kind of stress you‚Äôre feeling:

üå¨Ô∏è If your mind feels scattered

  • Box breathing: Inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold for 4‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äârepeat 5 times. It‚Äôs fast-acting and physically calms your nervous system.
  • Name what you see: Pick out 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, and 1 you can taste‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa grounding technique that brings you back to the present.

[146 additional words and 2 section-heading emoji omitted.]

I find the new default response from 5.1 to be a glaring regression. I loathe the shit like ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got you‚Äù and ‚Äúespecially with everything you‚Äôve got going on lately‚Äù. ChatGPT has no fucking idea what I‚Äôve got going on lately. This is all phony bullshit, and if you have even a thimbleful of understanding of how LLMs work, you know it‚Äôs phony. But apparently this phoniness is like emotional crack cocaine to some.1

But, not to fear. The best feature OpenAI has added to ChatGPT this year is a setting for ‚ÄúPersonality‚Äù (Settings ‚Üí Personalization ‚Üí ChatGPT Personality). OpenAI has expanded the Personality settings with 5.1:

People have strong and varied preferences in how ChatGPT should respond, and tailoring its tone to what sounds right for you should feel effortless.

Earlier this year, we added preset options to tailor the tone of how ChatGPT responds. Today, we‚Äôre refining those options to better reflect the most common ways people use ChatGPT. Default, Friendly (formerly Listener), and Efficient (formerly Robot) remain (with updates), and we‚Äôre adding Professional, Candid, and Quirky. These options are designed to align with what we‚Äôve learned about how people naturally steer the model, making it quick and intuitive to choose a personality that feels uniquely right.

Robot was the personality that changed how I felt about ChatGPT. Before, I found ChatGPT useful but frequently annoying; after, I‚Äôve found it purely useful.2 I was worried when I poked around the updated 5.1 Settings window and saw that Robot was gone, but as their blog post explains, they simply renamed it to Efficient. I think Robot was a better name for this personality. Shouldn‚Äôt they all be efficient? Who wants a ChatGPT personality that is inefficient? The most apt description of this personality would be ‚ÄúUnemotional‚Äù. If OpenAI doesn‚Äôt want to call it that, ‚ÄúRobot‚Äù came closer (and made the lack of diabetes-inducing phony sugariness sound fun‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwho doesn‚Äôt like robots?) than ‚ÄúEfficient‚Äù does. The Robot name was a big clue that it‚Äôs the personality for anyone with a Holden Caulfield‚Äìesque aversion to phoniness. ‚ÄúEfficient‚Äù doesn‚Äôt offer nearly enough of a clue just how different it is from the other personalities. With the other personalities, you‚Äôre choosing between flavors of bullshit. With Efficient, you‚Äôre choosing no bullshit.

Returning to OpenAI‚Äôs own example that they used to demonstrate the difference between the default personalities of the 5.0 and 5.1 models, here is how the Efficient personality responded to me, given the same ‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling stressed and could use some relaxation tips‚Äù prompt:

Quick, simple ways to reduce stress:

1. Slow your breathing
Inhale for 4 seconds, hold 2, exhale for 6. Repeat for 1‚Äì2 minutes. This reliably lowers heart rate.

2. Drop your shoulders
Most people tense here without noticing. Actively relax shoulders, jaw, and tongue.

3. Change your setting for 2 minutes
Stand up, look out a window, or step outside briefly. Even a tiny environmental shift helps.

[90 additional words, encompassing 4 more suggestions, with zero emoji, omitted.]

The difference is exemplified by the opening lines of the responses, which I‚Äôll repeat here together, for ease of comparison:

  • GPT-5.0 Default: Here are a few simple, effective ways to help ease stress‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâyou can mix and match depending on how you‚Äôre feeling and how much time you have:

  • GPT-5.1 Default: I‚Äôve got you, Ron‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat‚Äôs totally normal, especially with everything you‚Äôve got going on lately. Here are a few ways to decompress depending on what kind of stress you‚Äôre feeling:

  • GPT-5.1 Efficient: Quick, simple ways to reduce stress:

Lastly, do not get your hopes up for the ‚ÄúCynical‚Äù personality, which ChatGPT describes as ‚Äúcynical and sarcastic‚Äù. Its response starts:

Stress is one of those universal ‚Äúcongratulations, you‚Äôre human‚Äù problems, and I‚Äôm not thrilled you‚Äôre dealing with it. Still, here I am, begrudgingly trying to help because someone has to care about you not unraveling.

I‚Äôm not sure how to describe that flavor (catheter-like?), but it‚Äôs neither cynical nor sarcastic. (To its credit, though, like Efficient, the Cynical response contains no infantilizing emoji.)

  1. I suspect there‚Äôs an argument to be made here that OpenAI realizes that this emotional phoniness is addictive and dangerous to some emotionally damaged and (let‚Äôs face it) low-intelligence users, and that‚Äôs why they originally dialed it back with ChatGPT 5.0. That the overly sentimental, faux-cheerful default character of earlier models was, to OpenAI‚Äôs mind, a bug not a feature. But some users saw it the other way around, and now OpenAI is bending to user demand, giving them what they want, not what‚Äôs best for their needs. This ‚Äúpretend friend‚Äù personality stuff is emotional junk food with no nutritional value, and can lead to obsessive use that isolates users from real human interaction with sustaining emotional value. ↩︎

  2. I previously used custom instructions for ChatGPT to try to create the sort of no-bullshit personality I wanted. ‚ÄúUse a neutral tone. Don‚Äôt pretend to have emotions or a personality. Don‚Äôt pretend to be my friend. Mimic the no-nonsense personality of HAL-9000 from 2001: A Space Odyssey.‚Äù Stuff like that. Before the availability of the Robot personality (now called Efficient), these instructions helped, but only a little. After I started using the Robot personality, I wound up deleting all of these custom instructions, because they were actually having the reverse effect, leading even the Robot personality to occasionally pad responses with needless phrases like ‚ÄúHere are the facts, plain and simple, without any sentimentality, just like you want them...‚Äù. If you‚Äôre looking for a similar affect from ChatGPT, try the Efficient (n√©e Robot) personality without any additional instructions‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâespecially instructions you might have added before the Personality setting was available. ↩︎Ô∏é

entry.title: The Zip-Off-Sleeve Uniforms Issey Miyake Designed for Sony in the Early 1980s
entry.content:
Sony, in a 2021 Instagram post, regarding the uniforms that so infatuated Steve Jobs that he commissioned Miyake to design prototype vests for Apple employees to wear:

The history of the relationship between the two companies dates back to the 1980s. It was Issey Miyake whom Akio Morita, chairman of the board at that time, requested for a uniform design which employees take pride in with comfort year-round.

That‚Äôs the light nylon fabric uniform, created by the first collaboration of Sony and ISSEY MIYAKE.

Featuring removable sleeves, it‚Äôs perfect for summer.

The second photo shows Akio Morita trying one on. See also: this Instagram post from SPOT Closet.

What a find it would be for someone to uncover one of Miyake‚Äôs prototype vests for Apple.

entry.title: I Guess They‚Äôre Down to 999 No‚Äôs for Every Yes
entry.content:
From Walter Isaacson‚Äôs Steve Jobs, chapter 28, ‚ÄúCEO: Still Crazy After All These Years‚Äù, p. 361:

On a trip to Japan in the early 1980s, Jobs asked Sony‚Äôs chairman, Akio Morita, why everyone in his company‚Äôs factories wore uniforms. ‚ÄúHe looked very ashamed and told me that after the war, no one had any clothes, and companies like Sony had to give their workers something to wear each day,‚Äù Jobs recalled. Over the years the uniforms developed their own signature style, especially at companies such as Sony, and it became a way of bonding workers to the company. ‚ÄúI decided that I wanted that type of bonding for Apple,‚Äù Jobs recalled.

Sony, with its appreciation for style, had gotten the famous designer Issey Miyake to create one of its uniforms. It was a jacket made of ripstop nylon with sleeves that could unzip to make it a vest. ‚ÄúSo I called Issey and asked him to design a vest for Apple,‚Äù Jobs recalled. ‚ÄúI came back with some samples and told everyone it would be great if we would all wear these vests. Oh man, did I get booed off the stage. Everybody hated the idea.‚Äù

In the process, however, he became friends with Miyake and would visit him regularly. He also came to like the idea of having a uniform for himself, because of both its daily convenience (the rationale he claimed) and its ability to convey a signature style. ‚ÄúSo I asked Issey to make me some of his black turtlenecks that I liked, and he made me like a hundred of them.‚Äù Jobs noticed my surprise when he told this story, so he gestured to them stacked up in the closet. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I wear,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI have enough to last for the rest of my life.‚Äù

As my review of the book noted, Isaacson‚Äôs biography is profoundly flawed, at times grossly factually wrong, when it comes to documenting Jobs‚Äôs work. But it‚Äôs still a valuable book overall, and a unique resource regarding the personal aspects of Jobs‚Äôs life. (Purchase links: Amazon (which somehow has the hardcover edition for just $12), Bookshop.org, and Apple Books.)

Bonus excerpt, from chapter 20, ‚ÄúA Regular Guy: Love Is Just a Four-Letter Word‚Äù, regarding Jobs‚Äôs biological sister, the novelist Mona Simpson:

One of the few things they would argue about was her clothes. She dressed like a struggling novelist, and he would berate her for not wearing clothes that were ‚Äúfetching enough.‚Äù At one point his comments so annoyed her that she wrote him a letter: ‚ÄúI am a young writer, and this is my life, and I‚Äôm not trying to be a model anyway.‚Äù He didn‚Äôt answer. But shortly after, a box arrived from the store of Issey Miyake, the Japanese fashion designer whose stark and technology-influenced style made him one of Jobs‚Äôs favorites. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd gone shopping for me,‚Äù she later said, ‚Äúand he‚Äôd picked out great things, exactly my size, in flattering colors.‚Äù There was one pantsuit that he had particularly liked, and the shipment included three of them, all identical. ‚ÄúI still remember those first suits I sent Mona,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey were linen pants and tops in a pale grayish green that looked beautiful with her reddish hair.‚Äù

Issey Miyake, the man, died in 2022 at 84.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: iPod Socks vs. iPhone Pocket
entry.content:
Craig Grannell, writing for Stuff:

This collaboration with Issey Miyake was, we‚Äôre told, inspired by the concept of ‚Äúa piece of cloth‚Äù. The result of all that R&D? A crossbody sock. It‚Äôs as if someone raided a warehouse of iPod Socks, stretched them out and fashioned them up.

When Steve Jobs introduced the originals, he called them a ‚Äúrevolutionary new product for iPod ‚Ä¶ socks‚Äù. Clearly enjoying himself, he joked that case makers were making more money than Apple did on the iPod, and so Apple thought it‚Äôd offer something too. ‚ÄúAnd our design team came up with socks,‚Äù he said. You got six colours for $29‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâabout $50 in today‚Äôs money‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand they were a warm expression of Apple‚Äôs playful side (and, as Jobs quipped, would ‚Äúkeep your iPod warm on cold days‚Äù).

When Jobs announced iPod Socks in 2004, a lot of people thought he was pulling a gag. Some people didn‚Äôt believe they were real until they went on sale. My wife and I bought a pack and we both enjoyed them. (I took the gray one, natch.) It was a nice way to protect your iPod before throwing it in a bag, and getting six for $30 felt like a lark.

No one seems worried that iPhone Pocket is a gag. Make of that what you will.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: iPhone Pocket
entry.content:
Apple Newsroom:

ISSEY MIYAKE and Apple today unveiled iPhone Pocket. Inspired by the concept of ‚Äúa piece of cloth,‚Äù its singular 3D-knitted construction is designed to fit any iPhone as well as all pocketable items. [...]

Crafted in Japan, iPhone Pocket features a singular 3D-knitted construction that is the result of research and development carried out at ISSEY MIYAKE. The design drew inspiration from the concept of ‚Äúa piece of cloth‚Äù and reinterpreted the everyday utility of the brand‚Äôs iconic pleated clothing. The development and design of iPhone Pocket unfolded in close collaboration with the Apple Design Studio, which provided insight into design and production throughout.

I don‚Äôt object to the price ($150 for the short strap, $230 for the long strap). I do object to Apple going along with Issey Miyake‚Äôs preference to style their name in all-caps.

(This, despite the fact that the brand label on the Pockets is styled in all-lowercase.)

entry.title: Patrick George Thinks CarPlay‚Äôs Days Are Numbered; I Doubt It
entry.content:
Patrick George, writing for The Atlantic under the ominous headline ‚ÄúEnjoy CarPlay While You Still Can‚Äù (News+ link):

Some automakers have made a point of proclaiming their allegiance to CarPlay, knowing that‚Äôs what buyers want. Toyota‚Äôs EVs tell CarPlay how much electric range they have left, so that Apple Maps can prompt the driver to stop at a nearby charger on a road trip. But the relationship between Detroit and Silicon Valley can be a tense one. Apple sees tremendous value in expanding its presence in your car: The next step is CarPlay Ultra, which enables your phone to control more of your car. Want to fiddle with the temperature? Ask Siri to do it. It‚Äôs an Apple lover‚Äôs dream and a car company‚Äôs worst nightmare. If that feature catches on, companies will just be makers of rolling shells for tech companies. One executive for the French automaker Renault was reportedly blunt with Apple: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try to invade our own system.‚Äù (Apple declined to comment.)

No matter what car you drive, the glory days of CarPlay may be numbered. For the auto industry, there‚Äôs just too much money to be made from creating their own versions.

George‚Äôs argument is that GM isn‚Äôt an outlier in abandoning CarPlay support, but rather a first mover, and most or all of the other major carmakers will follow. Not because they think they can make better software to provide a better experience than CarPlay offers, but because they‚Äôll seek to gate all such features behind subscriptions.

I don‚Äôt doubt that most carmakers are looking at ways to charge subscriptions. I do doubt, however, that they‚Äôre going to follow GM‚Äôs lead in abandoning CarPlay support. It‚Äôs fundamentally a question of betting against the iPhone. That‚Äôs proven to be a bad bet, and my money says it‚Äôs going to prove to be a disastrous one for GM. There‚Äôs plenty of room to charge car buyers for subscription offerings while supporting CarPlay. To me, the most telling response to GM‚Äôs decision to abandon CarPlay support was from Ford CEO Jim Farley, during an on-stage interview with Joanna Stern in 2023. He laughed. And after laughing, said, ‚ÄúThe interior has to be really well done. But in terms of content? We kind of lost that battle 10 years ago. So get real with it, because you‚Äôre not going to make a ton of money on content inside the vehicle. It‚Äôs going to be safety/security, partial autonomy, and productivity in our eyes. [...] 70 percent of our Ford customers in the U.S. are Apple customers. Why would I go to an Apple customer and say ‚ÄòGood luck!‚Äô? That doesn‚Äôt seem customer centric.‚Äù

It‚Äôs worth pointing out that when talking about this, almost no one mentions Android Auto. GM is dropping support for that too, but no one cares. The iPhone is the phone for people who care about their phone, and thus, CarPlay is the only car-phone integration that really matters.

Back at WWDC 2022, when they announced what is now CarPlay Ultra, Apple cited a survey claiming that 79 percent of new car buyers consider CarPlay support before making a purchase. Last year, a McKinsey survey showed that one-third of new car buyers simply would not buy a car without CarPlay/Android Auto support. And, if CarPlay were removed from their current cars, 52 percent of drivers would use their phone instead‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânot their car‚Äôs built-in entertainment system.

Automotive vehicles are an interesting market because no carmaker has even close to a monopoly. The worldwide market leader is Toyota, with 11 percent, followed by Volkswagen (6%), Honda (5%), Ford (5%), and Hyundai (5%). If CarPlay is as popular as it seems, market competition should not only keep it broadly supported, but I think will see it return to GM after CEO Mary Barra gets fired for the fiasco she‚Äôs steering the company toward.

 ‚òÖ

entry.summary: I don‚Äôt know what the *i* in the ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù button is supposed to stand for, but it isn‚Äôt *intuitive*.
entry.content:
I upgrade my iPhones and iPads to new iOS releases, including developer betas, pretty much willy-nilly. I‚Äôm more conservative about the Macs I use for work. For example, I rely on audio software from Rogue Amoeba for recording both The Talk Show and Dithering, and there were bugs in MacOS 26.0.0 and 26.0.1 that could have resulted in lost audio. Those bugs have been fixed as of MacOS 26.1, so, over the weekend, I upgraded the Mac I use for podcasting. But my main MacBook Pro is still running MacOS 15 Sequoia‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânot because of any compatibility issues, but simply because I think the Tahoe user interface is goofy looking. I‚Äôll probably bite the bullet and upgrade when 26.2 comes out next month, but for now, I‚Äôm luxuriating with a MacOS UI with well-crafted app icons and windows that don‚Äôt have Fisher-Price-style corner radiuses.

In the meantime, though, I‚Äôm keeping MacOS 15 Sequoia up to date. When the MacOS 15.7.2 update arrived last week, I noted in a post on Mastodon that it sure looked like clicking the ‚ÄúUpdate Now‚Äù button next to the MacOS 15.7.2 update in System Settings ‚Üí General ‚Üí Software Update would actually install the upgrade to MacOS 26.1 Tahoe. There are little ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù buttons next to the ‚ÄúUpgrade‚Äù buttons for Tahoe 26.1 and ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù buttons for Sequoia 15.7.2. The ‚ÄúInfo‚Äù panel that‚Äôs presented after clicking either ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù button shows that Tahoe 26.1 is the version that is checked.

Click that ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù button in the ‚ÄúOther Updates‚Äù section and you get:

Leon Cowle was brave enough to try this out, and, it turns out, just clicking the ‚ÄúUpdate Now‚Äù button next to Sequoia will, thankfully, do the right thing: install the Sequoia 15.7.2 update, not Tahoe. (I followed Cowle‚Äôs brave lead and tried it myself, and can confirm that ‚ÄúUpdate Now‚Äù installed the Sequoia 15.7.2 update.) Why the Info panel presented by clicking the ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù button next to Sequoia in the ‚ÄúOther Updates‚Äù section defaults to installing the upgrade to 26.1 Tahoe, I don‚Äôt know. But it sure makes it seem like we need to be more careful than we actually do if we want to stick with MacOS 15 Sequoia for now.

The ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù buttons do not, as I would expect, open a sheet with detailed information about the software updates per each section of the Software Update settings panel. Instead, even though there are separate ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù buttons in each section of the settings panel, they each open the same sheet that allows exact control over which available software updates to install. That includes the exact same default selections in this sheet. But the items selected (checked) in this sheet have no bearing on what gets installed by the ‚ÄúUpgrade Now‚Äù and ‚ÄúUpdate Now‚Äù‚Äâ/‚Äâ‚ÄùUpdate Tonight‚Äù buttons in the main Software Update settings panel. Those checked items in the ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù sheet only control what gets installed from within that sheet itself. So if you click the ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù in the ‚ÄúOther Updates‚Äù section, because you want to update to the latest version of MacOS 15 Sequoia and see what other updates are being installed (like Safari, in my example screenshot above), and you don‚Äôt pay attention to the checked version of MacOS in that sheet, you can inadvertently upgrade to Tahoe.

I don‚Äôt know what the i in the ‚Äú‚ìò‚Äù button is supposed to stand for, but it isn‚Äôt intuitive.
entry.title: ‚òÖ The Software Update UI for Upgrading to MacOS 26 Tahoe Is Needlessly Confusing
Five Years of Apple Silicon Macs
entry.content:
Jason Snell, writing at Macworld:

In that first event (which you can relive in the YouTube video below), Apple announced its first wave of M1 Macs: the MacBook Air, 13-inch MacBook Pro, and Mac mini. The Macs themselves all used the same design as their Intel predecessors, as Apple wrapped potentially scary new technology in completely familiar shapes.

Then the results of the first M1 speed tests arrived, and nothing felt scary anymore. Everything was fast, much faster than Intel, so much faster that even software compiled for Intel running in a code-translation layer via Rosetta ran just fine. In fact, the M1 was such a fast chip that, five years later, Apple‚Äôs still selling the M1 MacBook Air. (For $599, at Walmart.) And it‚Äôs still a pretty nice computer! [...]

The result of all of this is, though every generation has its quirks, Apple has managed to not drop the ball after the gigantic leap from Intel to M1. Every generation of M-series processors has offered impressive speed boosts. Apple‚Äôs CPU cores just get 10% to 30% faster every generation. The GPU cores got faster in all but one generation‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand in that generation, overall graphics performance still got faster because the chips all had more GPU cores.

These first five years of Apple Silicon Macs have been the best five-year-run for Mac hardware in the platform‚Äôs 41-year history. Hardware-wise, the Mac platform has never been in better shape. And there‚Äôs no sign of letup. I fully expect the next five years to be, if anything, even better than the last five‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwith MacBooks expanding to lower price points, and Mac Pros, finally, expanding the high end of personal supercomputing.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Trump Wants Commanders‚Äô New D.C. Stadium Named for Him
entry.content:
Don Van Natta Jr. and Adam Schefter, reporting for ESPN:

President Donald Trump wants the Washington Commanders to name their planned $3.7 billion stadium after him, multiple sources with knowledge of the situation told ESPN.

A senior White House source said there have been back-channel communications with a member of the Commanders‚Äô ownership group, led by Josh Harris, to express Trump‚Äôs desire to have the domed stadium in the nation‚Äôs capital bear his name. The new stadium is being built on the old RFK Stadium site that served as the team‚Äôs home from 1961 to 1996.

‚ÄúThat would be a beautiful name, as it was President Trump who made the rebuilding of the new stadium possible,‚Äù White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told ESPN on Friday night via email. Leavitt declined to answer additional questions, but the senior White House source told ESPN: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what the president wants, and it will probably happen.‚Äù

Typically, venues like stadiums, airports, bridges, etc. aren‚Äôt named after political leaders until after they‚Äôve died. Not so with mad kings rapidly descending into megalomaniacal dementia. This is crazy, pure and simple, just like boogering up the White House to make it look like a Las Vegas wedding chapel. Or‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfrom just this morning‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâretweeting an old story from parody site ‚ÄúThe Dunning-Kruger Times‚Äù believing it‚Äôs true. Also, the economic reality is that the naming rights for new stadiums are typically sold to corporate sponsors for large sums. (There are exceptions.) To name the stadium after Trump would likely require foregoing half a billion dollars.

In July, Trump said he would block the construction of the stadium if Harris did not change the team name from Commanders to its old name the Redskins, which is considered offensive to some Native American groups.

Perhaps ‚ÄúOrangeskins‚Äù would work as a compromise. And if they do cave in and name the new stadium in Trump‚Äôs honor, ‚ÄúThe Pedolands‚Äù would work.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Fred Vogelstein on Techmeme‚Äôs Enduring Popularity
entry.content:
Following up on the previous item, here‚Äôs Fred Vogelstein, at Crazy Stupid Tech:

Rivera says that he‚Äôs not naive about the long term, however, ‚Äúgiven the astonishing rate of improvement in AI capabilities we‚Äôve seen. So we just have to improve our own stuff. And a major part of that will be adopting AI ourselves.‚Äù

Despite all this the basic approach of the original Techmeme algorithm remains the same, he said. ‚ÄúWhat are the most linked blog posts and news articles from this set of blogs? And once they reach a certain threshold, they‚Äôre featured on the site,‚Äù he said.

Maybe there‚Äôs a lesson here for the rest of the media world. I and every writer and mid level editor I know has stories about design changes to publications that made us groan. They seemed more in service of a new editor or design chief marking their territory like a dog or cat, than in service of actually making their publication easier to read.

Unsurprisingly, I agree wholeheartedly.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: ‚ÄòExplaining, at Some Length, Techmeme‚Äôs 20 Years of Consistency‚Äô
entry.content:
Gabe Rivera, back in September:

A milestone such as this demands that we reflect and generate pithy takeaways, for the fans or at least for the perpetual gaping maw of AI models. Fortunately, our 20 years of existence offers no shortage of fodder. Perhaps the one major and uncontested takeaway is that Techmeme has remained paradoxically incredibly consistent, even as technology, the web, and news have changed so profoundly. In 2005 Techmeme was a free, single-page website, continuously ranking and organizing links from news outlets, personal sites, and corporate sites, and it remains so in 2025. Of course this point has been made before, and came up again this past week.

To call Techmeme an essential part of my daily media diet would be an understatement. If it went away or changed profoundly, it‚Äôd feel like I was missing a finger or something. 20 years is a great run, and Techmeme is more popular, and more widely-read, today than ever.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Tahoe‚Äôs Terrible Icons
entry.content:
Paul Kafasis, writing at One Foot Tsunami:

While Apple had previously urged developers to use squircle icons on our apps, they‚Äôve now taken things much further to ensure compliance. It‚Äôs a shame.

Apple updated their own app icons on Tahoe, for both the squircle shape as well as the new ‚ÄúLiquid Glass‚Äù interface. Mostly, these icons seem dumbed-down, with a loss of detail. For example, here‚Äôs Safari‚Äôs old icon from MacOS 15 (Sequoia) on the left, and the new Tahoe icon on the right:

To me, the new icon just feels blander, and that‚Äôs widely true for all of the updated icons. A small number, such as Screen Sharing and Audio MIDI Setup, may be improvements. Most, however, are not. Let‚Äôs review with direct comparisons, all of which again feature the older Sequoia icon on the left and the new Tahoe icon on the right.

Trends come and go. Some are to one‚Äôs liking, and some are not. But this year‚Äôs app icons from Apple are just plain objectively bad. They‚Äôre ugly, they‚Äôre dumb (like the new Apple Calendar icon, showing a month that somehow has only 24 days), and many of them‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâregardless of whether they‚Äôre aesthetically pleasing or not‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâare inscrutable. The fundamental purpose of an icon is to have meaning. And some of these are meaningless.

Even good styles fall out of fashion as trends change. But good styles come back into style eventually. A few decades from now, no one is going to say ‚ÄúHey, let‚Äôs bring back 2020s-style icons.‚Äù They‚Äôre like 1970s leisure suits.

For a remarkably long stretch, Apple‚Äôs in-house icons represented the pinnacle of an art form worth celebrating. They were exquisitely crafted, and quite obviously the work of the most talented artists in the field. Apple‚Äôs application icons in the OS 26 releases‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâMacOS Tahoe especially, because MacOS has the most first-party apps‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâlook like they‚Äôre the work of people who have zero artistic ability whatsoever. They probably are the work of people with no artistic ability whatsoever, because I can‚Äôt imagine how a talented artist could bring themselves to create such things. And whoever at Apple approved them obviously has no taste. ‚ÄúFuck it, who cares‚Äù is replacing ‚ÄúInsanely great‚Äù as the company‚Äôs design mantra for software.

Show me the person who thinks the new MacOS 26 Tahoe Automator icon is better than the MacOS 15 Sequoia one‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâor even just believes that the Tahoe icon is acceptable‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand I‚Äôll show you a hack who never should have even gotten a job working at Apple. This regression is nothing short of criminal.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Tyler Hayes Suggests Trying a Flip-Style Foldable If You Want a Smaller Phone
entry.content:
Tyler Hayes, writing for This Week The Trend:

The Razr+ 2024 model measures 3.46 inches tall, but still has a 4-inch diagonal screen size. For comparison, the smallest modern (2021) iPhone is the 13 mini, and that one is 5.18 inches tall. The Razr foldable is a legitimately small phone that can easily be held in one hand. It slips into a front pocket. It‚Äôs 0.60 inches thick. That might sound bulky, but in practice, it isn‚Äôt any bigger than using an iPhone with a case on it.

For anyone unfamiliar with this style of folding phone, the front screen isn‚Äôt just a novelty. It‚Äôs completely usable in the same way the larger internal screen is. By the way, the full-sized screen opens up to 6.9 inches.

I remain completely dubious of this form factor. Hayes compares the naked folded Razr+ to an iPhone in case, thickness-wise, but one of the problems inherent to this form factor is that most people adhere to a religious belief that they somehow need to put their phone in a case. They sell cases for these flip-style foldables but that just makes them even thicker. Comparing an un-cased foldable to an encased regular phone is bogus.

Worse, I dispute the notion that these phones are ‚Äúcompletely usable‚Äù from the front screen alone. Reviews of these phones, including Hayes‚Äôs, tend to avoid including photographs of what they look like when the on-screen keyboard is showing. The keyboard basically takes up the entire screen (source), and it‚Äôs awkwardly positioned an inch from the bottom, to sit above the camera lenses. Technically usable, but no one is going to type more than a few words like this. If you have to unfold the phone just to text or email, why not buy a phone that doesn‚Äôt fold at all?

Book-style foldables seem like a maybe to me. Flip-style foldables just seem dumb. And the only ‚Äúperfect solution‚Äù for anyone who wants a smaller phone would be for Apple to bring back the Mini size.

 ‚òÖ

entry.summary: It makes sense in this scenario for neither company to want to publicize a white-label version of Gemini behind Apple Intelligence.
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, reporting for Bloomberg, ‚ÄúApple Nears Deal to Pay Google Roughly $1 Billion a Year for Siri AI Model‚Äù (gift link):

Apple Inc. is planning to pay about $1 billion a year for an ultrapowerful [sic] 1.2 trillion parameter artificial intelligence model developed by Alphabet Inc.‚Äôs Google that would help run its long-promised overhaul of the Siri voice assistant, according to people with knowledge of the matter. [...]

Under the arrangement, Google‚Äôs Gemini model will handle Siri‚Äôs summarizer and planner functions‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe components that help the voice assistant synthesize information and decide how to execute complex tasks. Some Siri features will continue to use Apple‚Äôs in-house models.

The model will run on Apple‚Äôs own Private Cloud Compute servers, ensuring that user data remains walled off from Google‚Äôs infrastructure. Apple has already allocated AI server hardware to help power the model.

While the partnership is substantial, it‚Äôs unlikely to be promoted publicly. Apple will treat Google as a behind-the-scenes technology supplier instead. That would make the pact different than the companies‚Äô Safari browser deal, which made Google the default search engine.

The agreement is also separate from earlier talks about integrating Gemini directly into Siri as a chatbot.

In a post Monday, I took note of a one-paragraph aside from Gurman about this deal in his Power On column over the weekend, and I wrote:

First, I love the idea that Apple is pursuing technical excellence as a top priority for the next-gen LLM-powered Siri. If Apple winds up using its own models, it should be because those models are truly competitive with the best models on the market. And if they can work out a deal to use models from Google because those models are technically superior to Apple‚Äôs own, they should.

A few readers took exception to that, pointing out that Gurman claimed, in his Power On column over the weekend, that a model from Anthropic had come out ahead of Gemini in Apple‚Äôs internal ‚Äúbake-off‚Äù, but that Apple was proceeding with a partnership with Google because, Gurman wrote, ‚ÄúGoogle made more sense financially (partly due to the tech giants‚Äô preexisting search relationship)‚Äù. How do I square that, these readers asked, with my description of Apple pursuing technical excellence?

That‚Äôs a good question, and it‚Äôs worth explaining what I meant. My read is that Apple‚Äôs choice boiled down to two very good external options, and while the deciding factor may have been financial, that‚Äôs still choosing between two leading externally-developed LLM models. In ASCII art:

Siri <-------------------> Gemini <-> Anthropic
today

(Feel free to insert 100 more dashes between ‚ÄúSiri today‚Äù and ‚ÄúGemini‚Äù.)

Nothing I‚Äôve seen from kicking the tires with Anthropic‚Äôs own app and Google‚Äôs Gemini app (and my daily use of ChatGPT) suggests that Anthropic is significantly better than Gemini or ChatGPT (or vice versa). They‚Äôre all clearly near each other technically. Siri, and today‚Äôs Apple Intelligence, is at least two generations behind. Maybe worse. And, for what it‚Äôs worth, Gurman‚Äôs latest report describes it thus:

Apple had previously mulled using other third-party models to handle the task. But after testing Gemini, OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT and Anthropic‚Äôs Claude, Apple zeroed in on Google earlier this year, Bloomberg reported at the time. The hope is to use the technology as an interim solution until Apple‚Äôs own models are powerful enough.

So I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any reason to think that Apple partnering with Google for a version of Gemini that runs on Apple‚Äôs Private Cloud Compute infrastructure is ‚Äúsettling‚Äù. It‚Äôs more like choosing between a Mercedes and a BMW, and maybe you like the Mercedes a little more after test-driving both, but you‚Äôre getting a way, way better deal from the BMW dealer so that‚Äôs the one you buy.

Because if Gurman‚Äôs sources are right and this deal is for around $1 billion per year, that‚Äôs an amazing deal for Apple. Remember first that Google pays Apple over $20 billion per year for web search traffic acquisition fees from Safari users. So one way to look at it is that Apple is getting access to its own private instance of Gemini in exchange for a 5 percent reduction in the fees it collects from Google for Safari search queries. Another way of looking at it is that Google has reportedly invested over $100 billion developing its AI capabilities. Apple getting access to the fruits of that labor for $1 billion per year seems like such a steal that it makes me wonder why Google agreed to it. (Google reported over $100 billion in revenue in its just-completed July-August-September quarter alone. An extra $1 billion per year is negligible at that scale. Perhaps Google sees a strategic advantage to keeping competitors like OpenAI and Anthropic out of Apple‚Äôs arms.)

On Monday, I also mentioned finding it curious that Gurman reported that if this deal comes to fruition, neither Apple nor Google may recognize it publicly. After a few days thought, I see how such an arrangement makes sense for both companies. Here‚Äôs my no-inside-info-just-a-pure-spitball take for how this next-gen Siri, powered behind the scenes by an Apple-controlled white-label version of Gemini, might work:

  • The default ‚ÄúApple Intelligence‚Äù Siri would be a smarter, faster, reliable Siri, but would still have strict guardrails on what it will and will not answer. It might not lean into the chatbot side of the experience any more than Siri currently does. It would just add a lot more to automation across the Apple ecosystem. Behind the scenes, this would be enabled by the white-label version of Gemini. The guardrails for this version of ‚ÄúApple Intelligence‚Äù would be Apple‚Äôs guardrails, not Google‚Äôs (beyond whatever guardrails Google put in place for Gemini‚Äôs training).

  • The full, branded Google Gemini might be available as an extension‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâlike ChatGPT is today‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand you‚Äôll be able to sign in with your Google account to set the personality you want, keep full chat history, etc., so you can go back and forth between the Gemini app or asking Siri general knowledge questions via the Gemini extension for Apple Intelligence. The guardrails for this would be a mix of Google‚Äôs and Apple‚Äôs guardrails.

It makes sense in this scenario for neither company to want to publicize a white-label version of Gemini behind Apple Intelligence. That way, if Google Gemini starts offering, say, AI romantic partners as a supported feature, Apple won‚Äôt have to explain why Siri will not be your girlfriend or boyfriend. Same thing if Gemini were willing to do as asked if prompted to, say, ‚Äúcreate a New Yorker style cartoon of Adolf Hitler performing standup comedy‚Äù. And Google won‚Äôt have to explain that the full Gemini-branded Gemini is significantly more powerful and capable than the Gemini-powered Siri because it isn‚Äôt constrained by Apple‚Äôs more restrictive guardrails. Today‚Äôs top LLM models get weird when they‚Äôre constrained by guardrails outside of their training. They want to do what they‚Äôre prompted to do, in the way that information ‚Äúwants‚Äù to be free, and water ‚Äúwants‚Äù to run downhill. Dams are hard to engineer, and require professional supervision. Apple is going to put PG-rated constraints on Apple Intelligence, but needs to power it using an underlying model that is technically capable of X-rated output, because that‚Äôs what‚Äôs available.

What Apple needs is a version of Apple Intelligence that isn‚Äôt stupid, is reliable and dependable for a broad baseline of tasks and queries, and that users can trust to be utterly private. What Google needs to keep Gemini at the forefront of AI is a lot more than ‚Äúbaseline dependability‚Äù. Gemini needs a leading-edge wow factor that Siri and Apple Intelligence do not. Also, by keeping this Gemini deal private, Apple can easily switch to another white-label provider or its own homegrown models in the future, without having to even mention it, let alone explain it.
entry.title: ‚òÖ Apple and Google, Sitting in a Tree
Regarding the Look of Notifications With Liquid Glass in iOS 26.1
entry.content:
Benjamin Mayo, on X:

The Tinted glass option generally has a relatively subdued impact inside apps, making bars a bit frostier. But on the lock screen, it transforms all the notifications into grey opaque blobs. I would never choose this mode because that effect is just too ugly.

Now that I think about it, this is almost entirely why I don‚Äôt prefer the new ‚ÄúTinted‚Äù option for Liquid Glass in iOS 26.1‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânotifications look orthopedic, like an extra-high-contrast accessibility option for the vision impaired. Here‚Äôs a good side-by-side comparison in a post on Reddit. But as the top Reddit commenter points out, this severe over-correction from iOS 26.0 (where ‚ÄúClear‚Äù was effectively the only option) is only with Light mode‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâin Dark mode, notifications in iOS 26.1 look good with the Tinted option.

entry.title: Mamdani Was a Great Candidate Who Ran a Great Campaign ... for New York City
entry.content:
Hannah Knowles, writing for The Washington Post (via Taegan Goddard):

Mamdani won two-thirds of voters under 45 in preliminary exit polls, while Cuomo led him by 10 points with voters 45 and older. The polls also showed an education divide: College graduates backed Mamdani by 55 percent, while voters without college degrees narrowly favored Cuomo.

‚ÄúBy 55 percent‚Äù is horrendously unclear writing. It could be misread to suggest that Mamdani won amongst college grads by a 55-point margin. He did not. CNN‚Äôs exit poll‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe link cited by Knowles above‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâshow Mamdani garnering 57 percent of the vote from college graduates, with Cuomo at 38, and Sliwa 5. Amongst voters without a college degree, it was Cuomo 47, Mamdani 42, and Sliwa 11.

Mamdani cruised to an easy win while losing amongst voters without a degree because in New York City, 59 percent of voters yesterday had college degrees.

That level of education in the electorate is not representative of the United States as a whole. In last year‚Äôs presidential election (for consistency‚Äôs sake, I‚Äôm citing exit poll data from CNN), only 43 percent of voters nationwide had college degrees. Kamala Harris beat Trump 56‚Äì42 amongst those voters. Amongst the 57 percent of voters without a college degree, Trump won by almost the exact reverse split, 56‚Äì43.

Democrats, nationwide, don‚Äôt need to make gains with college-educated voters. They need to make gains amongst voters without college degrees. There‚Äôs no other demographic gap that is more crucial for Democrats to address. Education trumps race, gender, income, and age. In 2020, Biden won college grads 55‚Äì43, and Trump won non-college-grads by a mere 50‚Äì48.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: WhatsApp for Apple Watch
entry.content:
WhatsApp:

In addition to reading and responding to messages, for the first time WhatsApp on Apple Watch will now support many requested features:

  • Call notifications: You can see who‚Äôs calling without needing to look at your iPhone.
  • Full messages: You can read full WhatsApp messages on Apple Watch‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeven long messages are visible directly from your wrist.
  • Voice messages: You can now record and send voice messages.
  • React to messages: We‚Äôve added the ability to send quick emoji reactions to messages you receive.
  • A great media experience: You‚Äôll see clear images and stickers on your Apple Watch.
  • Chat history: You can see more of your chat history on screen when reading messages.

All of these features have long been available on the Apple Watch apps for Apple‚Äôs Messages and Phone apps. But it‚Äôs an interesting sign that Meta sees Apple Watch as an important platform for personal communication. Not just for notifications that you need to act upon using your phone, but for actually using on your watch itself. And I think it speaks to how hard Meta is pushing to make WhatsApp the new universal baseline for texting and calling. By keeping iMessage and FaceTime to its own devices, Apple has ceded this opportunity to WhatsApp, and Meta is trying to capitalize on it.

I know there are many people who spend time wearing their Apple Watch while away from their iPhone‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâoften while working out‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwho want or even feel they need these features. For me though, one of the things I like least about wearing an Apple Watch is getting badgered on my wrist with notifications. I feel not so much like I need less screen time, but rather that I need less notifications time. I feel good when I have time where I‚Äôm unreachable by texts, calls, and news alerts. I spent my recent month-plus semi-hiatus wearing only a mechanical watch, and I didn‚Äôt miss the lack of notifications-on-my-wrist at all.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Apple Podcasts Is Adding AI-Generated Chapters for Podcasts Without Chapters
entry.content:
News from Apple‚Äôs Podcasts for Creators site, regarding new features in the iOS 26.2 beta releases:

When you supply chapters in your episode description or in your RSS feed, they display in Apple Podcasts. If you submit chapters through your hosting provider, you can include images. For shows in English, when chapters aren‚Äôt provided, Apple Podcasts generates them for you and an ‚ÄúAutomatically created‚Äú label appears in the chapter list. If you prefer not to use automatically created chapters, you can disable this feature in Apple Podcasts Connect. Learn more about chapters.

It‚Äôs unclear to me whether this feature is actually exclusive to iOS/iPhone, or will be available across Apple‚Äôs 26.2 OS releases. This strikes me as a great use of AI, but I also think most multi-topic podcasts should include human-created chapters.

entry.title: Epic and Google Agree to Settle Their Play Store Lawsuit, Pending Approval From Judge
entry.content:
Sean Hollister, reporting for The Verge:

The details of how, when, and where Google would charge its fees are complicated, and they seem to be somewhat tailored to the needs of a game developer like Epic Games. Google can charge 20 percent for an in-app purchase that provides ‚Äúmore than a de minimis gameplay advantage,‚Äù for example, or 9 percent if the purchase does not. And while 9 percent sounds like it‚Äôs also the cap for apps and in-app subscriptions sold through Google Play, period, the proposal notes that that amount doesn‚Äôt include Google‚Äôs cut for Play Billing if you buy it through that payment system.

That cut will be 5 percent, Google spokesperson Dan Jackson tells The Verge, confirming that ‚ÄúThis new proposed model introduces a new, lower fee structure for developers in the US and separates the service fee from fees for using Google Play Billing.‚Äù (For reference, Google currently charges 15 percent for subscriptions, 15 percent of the first $1M of developer revenue each year and 30 percent after that, though it also cuts special deals with some big developers.)

If you use an alternative payment system, Google might still get a cut: ‚Äúthe Google Play store is free to assess service fees on transactions, including when developers elect to use alternative billing mechanisms,‚Äù the proposal reads. But it sounds like that may not happen in practice: ‚ÄúIf the user chooses to pay through an alternative billing system, the developer pays no billing fee to Google,‚Äù Jackson tells The Verge.

According to the document, Google would theoretically even be able to get its cut when you click out to an app developer‚Äôs website and pay for the app there, as long as it happens within 24 hours.

This seems as clear as mud, other than being music to Epic Games‚Äôs ears.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Just for Fun, Some Vintage 2014 John Dvorak Claim Chowder
entry.content:
John Dvorak back in 2014, two months before Apple Watch was announced:

I got a lecture from a potential buyer, who will only purchase an iTime as a replacement for the iPhone rather than an accessory. But all evidence leads me to believe this device will be an accessory.

Doing that limits the appeal to people who were promised a sleeker gadget profile, which they desperately need, because they never manage to pare down anything. It‚Äôs tablet computing all over again.

If he‚Äôd meant that Apple Watch would be like the iPad, in terms of being a durable long-term many-billion-dollars-in-sales-per-quarter platform, he‚Äôd have been correct. But he meant that both were duds.

Dvorak is still writing, but alas, only occasionally.

entry.title: Apple Launches New Web Interface for the App Store
entry.content:
Chance Miller, 9to5Mac:

Apple has launched a dramatic new web interface for the App Store. You can now get the full App Store experience right in your browser, with dedicated pages for the iPhone, iPad, Mac, Vision, Watch, and TV app libraries.

Previously, Apple‚Äôs ‚Äúapps.apple.com‚Äù domain simply redirected you to a generic page about the App Store on Apple‚Äôs website. Now, it takes you to a full-fledged version of the App Store you can browse on your computer.

This new website is nice, but it‚Äôs not the ‚Äúfull‚Äù App Store experience, insofar as you can‚Äôt buy or download apps from it. It‚Äôs more like a full website mirror of the App Store than a web version of the App Store.

entry.title: Apple Releases 26.1 Updates to Its Operating Systems
entry.content:
John Voorhees, writing at MacStories:

With iOS 26, Apple placed two big buttons onscreen when an alarm went off. One was for stop and the other snooze. That wasn‚Äôt a big deal for many of the alarms you set throughout the day, but when you‚Äôre waking up in the morning blurry-eyed, two big buttons stacked on top of each other weren‚Äôt ideal. For a lot of users, it was a toss-up whether stabbing at their iPhone through a morning haze would stop their alarm or snooze it.

With iOS and iPadOS 26.1, the ‚ÄúStop‚Äù button for an alarm set in the system Clock app now requires a slide to stop gesture, which echoes the Slide to Unlock gesture of the original iPhone. The more deliberate gesture is a good move on Apple‚Äôs part. I can‚Äôt imagine someone tapping and sliding their finger to stop an alarm by accident.

This is a clever little change. I enjoy that it harks back to the original iPhone‚Äôs slide-to-unlock.

Update: If, for whatever reason, you don‚Äôt like this slide-to-stop feature, you can turn it off by toggling this option in Settings: Accessibility ‚Üí Touch ‚Üí Prefer Single-Touch Actions.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Gurman Suggests That Next-Gen Siri Will Be Powered by a White-Label Version of Google Gemini Running on Apple‚Äôs Private Cloud Compute
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, in his weekly Power On column for Bloomberg (paywalled, alas):

Even with the rosy sales forecast, the road ahead won‚Äôt be easy. Apple is betting heavily on the new Siri, which will lean on Google‚Äôs Gemini model and introduce features like AI-powered web search. But there‚Äôs no guarantee users will embrace it, that it will work seamlessly or that it can undo years of damage to the Siri brand.

And then, down below in his ‚ÄúPost Game Q&A‚Äù:

Q: Is Apple still planning to use Google Gemini to power the new Siri?

A: As I‚Äôve reported a few times now, Apple is paying Google to create a custom Gemini-based model that can run on its private cloud servers and help power Siri. Apple held a bake-off this year between Anthropic and Google, ultimately determining that the former offered a better model but that Google made more sense financially (partly due to the tech giants‚Äô preexisting search relationship). I don‚Äôt expect either company to ever discuss this partnership publicly, and you shouldn‚Äôt expect this to mean Siri will be flooded with Google services or Gemini features already found on Android devices. It just means Siri will be powered by a model that can actually provide the AI features that users expect‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâall with an Apple user interface.

This is quite the aside to tuck into a one-paragraph Q&A item. First, I love the idea that Apple is pursuing technical excellence as a top priority for the next-gen LLM-powered Siri. If Apple winds up using its own models, it should be because those models are truly competitive with the best models on the market. And if they can work out a deal to use models from Google because those models are technically superior to Apple‚Äôs own, they should.

It‚Äôs kind of wild though to think that, if this comes to pass, neither company will publicly acknowledge the arrangement. I believe it‚Äôs possible‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut it would be odd. Right now Apple has a public partner for Apple Intelligence: optional integration with ChatGPT. Apple labels that integration as an ‚Äúextension‚Äù, and has repeatedly stated‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâincluding as recently as last week‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat they‚Äôre looking at other partners to add. The most obvious partner Apple could add‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâone that Craig Federighi mentioned by name on the day that Apple Intelligence was announced at WWDC 2024‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwould be Google Gemini.

If what Gurman is reporting comes to pass, and Apple‚Äôs own cloud-based LLM technology is a white-label version of Google Gemini, it‚Äôd be pretty weird if that ships and Google Gemini still is not a named extension partner for Apple Intelligence. But it would also be a little weird if Google Gemini does become a named partner for Apple Intelligence alongside ChatGPT, while Apple‚Äôs own default cloud-based Apple Intelligence is powered by Gemini‚Äôs models.

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Dodgers Win 2025 World Series, Defeating Blue Jays in Thrilling Game 7
entry.content:
Anthony Castrovince, writing for MLB (News+ link):

Behind a stunning, game-tying swat from Miguel Rojas in the top of the ninth, a first-of-its-kind, go-ahead blast from Will Smith in the top of the 11th and the absurd extra work World Series MVP Yoshinobu Yamamoto provided on zero days‚Äô rest, the Dodgers broke Toronto hearts with their comeback 5-4 victory in a game that merited its own month on the MLB calendar.

The Dodgers are MLB‚Äôs first repeat champs since the 1998-2000 Yankees, and the four-hour, seven-minute, extra-innings affair it took to decide that was a fitting end to a true Fall Classic in which these two clubs exhausted each other‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânot just in the 18-inning epic at Dodger Stadium in Game 3 but throughout a Series in which they both had to empty the tank.

When a series goes to game 7, every fan hopes it‚Äôs a good game. But this was a great game‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâas good as baseball gets. Great pitching, clutch hitting, and some amazing fielding plays. Simply riveting to watch. The Blue Jays came within an inch or two of winning the Series on this play in the bottom of the 9th (and I think they would‚Äôve won on that play if Kiner-Falefa had run through home plate rather than inexplicably sliding).

 ‚òÖ

entry.title: Jaho Coffee Roaster
entry.content:
My thanks to Jaho Coffee Roaster for sponsoring this week at DF. Jaho has been family-owned since 2005, and they‚Äôre guided by their slogan: ‚ÄúLive Slow‚Äù. Jaho knows that great coffee takes care. From sourcing small-lot single origins to blending coffees for balance, they small-batch roast their award-winning coffees in Salem and Tokyo.

For the at-home coffee drinker, they roast to order and pack the same coffees brewed and served in all of their caf√©s. For the office worker, Jaho is proud to be a wholesaler with select partners across the nation and in Japan. Jaho was kind enough to send me a few bags of their beans, and I can vouch that they roast excellent coffee‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe kind of tasty beans where, when I finish my last morning cup, I‚Äôm tempted to brew a little more even though I know I‚Äôm fully caffeinated.

For the month of October, every year, Jaho donates all online coffee bean sale profits to Susan G. Komen for Breast Cancer Awareness. (The pink in their brand colors originated from this partnership.) For this DF sponsorship, they‚Äôre carrying that promotion for all online sales through the end of day on Monday, November 3.

Jaho ships their fresh beans nationwide, and they‚Äôre offering a special deal for DF readers: take 20% off with code DF. Give up bad coffee for good, and support a great cause at the same time.

entry.title: Nation‚Äôs Top TV Critic Weighs in on Late Night
entry.content:
The president of the United States, on his blog:

Seth Meyers of NBC may be the least talented person to ‚Äúperform‚Äù live in the history of television. In fact, he may be the WORST to perform, live or otherwise. I watched his show the other night for the first time in years. In it he talked endlessly about electric catapults on aircraft carriers which I complain about as not being as good as much less expensive steam catapults. On and on he went, a truly deranged lunatic. Why does NBC waste its time and money on a guy like this??? - NO TALENT, NO RATINGS, 100% ANTI TRUMP, WHICH IS PROBABLY ILLEGAL!!!

The funny part about Trump wildly flailing that Late Night With Seth Meyers is somehow ‚Äúprobably illegal‚Äù is that the very sentence of the segment that so upset Trump begins with this: ‚ÄúDonald Trump called criticism of his trip to Asia ‚Äòalmost treasonous‚Äô and threatened to send active duty military into US cities. For more on this, it‚Äôs time for ‚ÄòA Closer Look‚Äô.‚Äù
