entry.title: Uni Watch: 1999‚Äì2025
entry.content:
Paul Lukas, founder of Uni Watch:

Due to a perfect storm of negative developments, I have reluctantly come to the unfortunate conclusion that continuing to publish Uni Watch is no longer viable. This will be the site‚Äôs final post.

Yes, I‚Äôm serious. And no, this isn‚Äôt a Halloween-related prank. Uni Watch is shutting down, for real.

I realize this news probably comes as a shock and that you no doubt have lots of questions, so let‚Äôs shift into Q&A mode. [...]

Will the site‚Äôs archive remain on the web?

No, unfortunately. Most of the archive‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeverything but the past few days‚Äô worth of content‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâhas already been taken down. The rest of the site, including this post, will be taken offline soon, probably around next Wednesday.

26 years is a hell of a run (dating back to 1999, a few years before Uni Watch became a standalone site), but I don‚Äôt understand why sites don‚Äôt leave their archives standing when they close down. It shouldn‚Äôt cost much to keep the domain name registered and a static version of the site‚Äôs archive online.

Uni Watch, to me, epitomized a certain mindset from the early web. To wit, that there ought to be a blog (or two or three) dedicated to every esoteric interest under the sun. You want to obsess about sports team uniform designs? Uni Watch was there. For a good long stretch, there seemingly was a blog (or two or three) dedicated to just about everything. That‚Äôs starting to wane. New sites aren‚Äôt rising to take the place of retiring ones.

 ‚òÖ

entry.summary: Most people‚Äôs primary computing devices are their phones‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand even for people whose primary devices are desktop computers, their phones are much-used satellite devices. And on both iOS and Android alike, people live their mobile digital lives through native apps, not websites.
entry.content:
OpenAI, one week ago:

Today we‚Äôre introducing ChatGPT Atlas, a new web browser built with ChatGPT at its core.

AI gives us a rare moment to rethink what it means to use the web. Last year, we added search in ChatGPT so you could instantly find timely information from across the internet‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand it quickly became one of our most-used features. But your browser is where all of your work, tools, and context come together. A browser built with ChatGPT takes us closer to a true super-assistant that understands your world and helps you achieve your goals.

A few minutes into the 22-minute introduction video, Ben Goodger,1 engineering lead for Atlas, says:

‚ÄúWe wanted to make sure that Atlas didn‚Äôt feel like your old browser, just with a chat button that was bolted on. But instead, we made ChatGPT the beating heart of Atlas.‚Äù

After giving it a try over the last week, to me Atlas feels like ‚Ä¶ Chrome with a chat button bolted on. I do not see the appeal, at all, despite being a daily user of ChatGPT. Atlas offers nothing to me that‚Äôs better than using Safari as a standalone browser and ChatGPT‚Äôs excellent native Mac app as a standalone AI chatbot. But, for me, my browser is not ‚Äúwhere all of [my] work, tools, and context come together‚Äù. I use an email app for email, a notes app for notes, a text editor and blog editor for writing and programming, a photos app for my photo library, a native feed reader app for feed reading, etc. My web browser is for browsing pages on the web. Perhaps this sort of browser/chat hybrid appeals better to people who live the majority of their desktop-computing lives in browser tabs.

  • The main interface isn‚Äôt a combo search/location field, but rather a chat/location field. Instead of getting search results for a query, you get a chat response. If I wanted this I‚Äôd just ask my prompt in ChatGPT. Oftentimes‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâusually, even‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI really do want a list of search results, and I want them fast. ChatGPT responses in Atlas are not a list of web pages, and are‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâcompared to Google Search or my preferred search engine, Kagi‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâvery slow. ChatGPT is many things but a good search engine replacement it is not. But that seems to be the entire premise of Atlas.

  • Atlas offers an agent mode where it actually surfs the web for you. One of the demos from their launch video involved getting a list of ingredients from a recipe on a web page, and then allowing Atlas to buy all those ingredients for you. That seems crazy to me. Do not want.

  • Atlas is a Chromium browser, supports Chrome extensions, and but currently is only available for the Mac. It‚Äôs not particularly Mac-like though, as Michael Tsai notes:

    Alas, it doesn‚Äôt support AppleScript and has System Settings‚Äìstyle preferences.

    System Settings-style preferences are certainly better than Chrome-style ‚Äúsettings in a web page tab‚Äù, though. Also, in my testing, Atlas doesn‚Äôt make good use of Apple Passwords for autofill.

  • ChatGPT is running a promotion that offers users increased rate limits if they make‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand keep‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâAtlas their default web browser. I‚Äôve never before seen a web browser offer any sort of incentive like this for making it your default. This promotion strikes me as simultaneously clever and icky.

  • Simon Willison‚Äôs initial thoughts echo my own:

    I continue to find this entire category of browser agents deeply confusing.

    The security and privacy risks involved here still feel insurmountably high to me‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI certainly won‚Äôt be trusting any of these products until a bunch of security researchers have given them a very thorough beating. [...]

    I also find these products pretty unexciting to use. I tried out agent mode and it was like watching a first-time computer user painstakingly learn to use a mouse for the first time. I have yet to find my own use-cases for when this kind of interaction feels useful to me, though I‚Äôm not ruling that out.

  • Lastly, Anil Dash‚Äôs assessment is rather scathing, ‚ÄúThe Browser That‚Äôs Anti-Web‚Äù:

    In the demo for Atlas, the OpenAI team shows a user trying to find a Google Doc from their browser history. A normal user would type keywords like ‚Äúatlas design‚Äù and see their browser show a list of recent pages. They would recognize the phrase ‚ÄúGoogle Docs‚Äù or the icon, and click on it to get back to where they were.

    But in the OpenAI demo, the team member types out:

    search web history for a doc about atlas core design

    This is worse in every conceivable way. It‚Äôs slower, more prone to error, and redundant. But it also highlights one of the biggest invisible problems: you‚Äôre switching ‚Äúmodes‚Äù. Normally, an LLM‚Äôs default mode is to create plausible extrapolations based on its training data. Basically, it‚Äôs supposed to make things up. But this demo has to explicitly walk you through ‚Äúnow it‚Äôs time to go search my browser history‚Äù because it‚Äôs coercing the AI to look through local content.

    Chat is a great interface for, well, chatting. People love texting. And it turns out that chat conversations are a very good user interface for interacting with LLMs. We humans enjoy texting with other humans, and we enjoy texting with LLMs. But typed-out text commands are not a good user interface at all for browsing the web. We had an entirely text-based Internet before the World Wide Web, and the point-and-click visual metaphor of the Web won out.

    Dash, later on:

    It‚Äôs no coincidence that hundreds of people who work at OpenAI, including many of the most powerful executives, are alumni of Facebook/Meta, especially during the era of many of that company‚Äôs most egregious abuses of people‚Äôs privacy. In the marketing materials and demonstrations of Atlas, OpenAI‚Äôs team describes the browser as being able to be your ‚Äúagent‚Äù, performing tasks on your behalf.

    But in reality, you are the agent for ChatGPT.

    During setup, Atlas pushes very aggressively for you to turn on ‚Äúmemories‚Äù (where it tracks and stores everything you do and uses it to train an AI model about you) and to enable ‚ÄúAsk ChatGPT‚Äù on any website, where it‚Äôs following along with you as you browse the web. By keeping the ChatGPT sidebar open while you browse, and giving it permission to look over your shoulder, OpenAI can suddenly access all kinds of things on the internet that they could never get to on their own.

    This jibes with my impression after giving Atlas a try. The point of it doesn‚Äôt seem to be to provide a better web browser for me to use, but rather, to provide ChatGPT with the personal context of my digital life that it otherwise couldn‚Äôt get.

That last point raises the question of just how stable we should consider the Apple-OpenAI partnership for ChatGPT-backed Apple Intelligence features. Apple‚Äôs goal for a ‚Äúmore personalized Siri‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe whole thing Apple promised at WWDC 2024 but had to postpone for a full year early this year‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis for the ecosystem of native apps on Apple platforms, particularly iOS and MacOS, to serve as the personal knowledge context for personalized AI features through App Intents. That‚Äôs the basis for the ‚ÄúWhen is my mom‚Äôs flight arriving?‚Äù type of interaction that Apple has promised, but still has not delivered. The premise of Atlas (and its brethren AI-integrated browsers like The Browser Company‚Äôs Dia and Perplexity‚Äôs Comet) is that you should live your entire desktop computing life inside your browser, which in turn will give the AI agent that is integrated with your browser the contextual knowledge for your entire life.

OpenAI‚Äôs ambitions are clearly at odds with Apple‚Äôs.

OpenAI‚Äôs advantage here is that ChatGPT is the most popular LLM chatbot in the world, by far. Apple doesn‚Äôt even have an LLM chatbot of its own, let alone a good or popular one. But Apple‚Äôs advantage is a big one: most people don‚Äôt live their digital lives on desktop computers, where it‚Äôs an option to do most things in a web browser. Most people‚Äôs primary computing devices are their phones‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand even for people whose primary devices are desktop computers, their phones are much-used satellite devices. And on both iOS and Android alike, people live their mobile digital lives through native apps, not websites.

  1. Goodger is a titanic figure in the web browser world, having helped create Mozilla Firefox in the early 2000s, and then joining Google in 2005 to help create Chrome. I noted last year that Goodger leaving Google for OpenAI was a pretty clear sign that OpenAI was creating its own web browser. ↩︎
entry.title: ‚òÖ Thoughts, Observations, and Links Regarding ChatGPT Atlas

entry.summary: The best time to adjust the rules of the App Store‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâits exclusivity on app distribution for the entire iOS platform, the exclusivity of Apple‚Äôs IAP for purchasing digital content, the commission percentage splits on IAP‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwas over a decade ago. The next best time to make those adjustments is now.
entry.content:
Sam Tobin, reporting last week for Reuters:

Apple abused its dominant position by charging app developers unfair commissions, a London tribunal ruled on Thursday, in a blow which could leave the U.S. tech company on the hook for hundreds of millions of pounds in damages. The Competition Appeal Tribunal (CAT) ruled against Apple after a trial of the lawsuit, which was brought on behalf of millions of iPhone and iPad users in the United Kingdom.

The CAT ruled that Apple had abused its dominant position from October 2015 until the end of 2020 by shutting out competition in the app distribution market and by ‚Äúcharging excessive and unfair prices‚Äù as commission to developers. [...] The case had been valued at around 1.5 billion pounds ($2 billion) by those who brought it. A hearing next month will decide how damages are calculated and Apple‚Äôs application for permission to appeal.

Dan Moren and I discussed this at some length in the new episode of The Talk Show that dropped over the weekend. What makes this ruling interesting isn‚Äôt that it‚Äôs particularly significant or different from other regulatory/antitrust investigations around the world. It‚Äôs the fact that it‚Äôs completely in line with other regulatory/antitrust investigations regarding the App Store (and Play Store) from around the world.

When is the last time an investigation regarding the legality of the App Store‚Äôs dominant market position went in Apple‚Äôs favor, in any country? I can‚Äôt recall one. Apple is clearly fighting a losing battle here. Whether Apple ought to be losing all these legal and regulatory battles regarding the App Store is, from a strategic standpoint, almost irrelevant. The obvious fact is, they are losing them.

Apple has approached all this regulatory conflict from a perspective that they‚Äôre right, and the regulators are wrong. That the App Store, as Apple wants it, is (a) good for users, (b) fair to developers, and (c) competitive, not anti-competitive, legally. But even if Apple is correct about that, at some point, after being handed loss after loss in rulings from courts and regulatory bodies around the globe, shouldn‚Äôt they change their strategy and start trying to offer their own concessions, rather than wait for bureaucrat-designed concessions to be forced upon them?

However Apple thinks all of this should work out is not the way it is working out. The best time to adjust the rules of the App Store‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâits exclusivity on app distribution for the entire iOS platform, the exclusivity of Apple‚Äôs IAP for purchasing digital content, the commission percentage splits on IAP‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwas over a decade ago. The next best time to make those adjustments is now.
entry.title: ‚òÖ Apple Loses Landmark U.K. Lawsuit Over App Store Commissions
